Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to develop a new type of optoelectronic nano-hand by integrating fiber optics, electronics, and NEMS/MEMS (nano- or micro- electromechanical systems) in a unified platform. The PIs plan to carry out four core research tasks. First, they will demonstrate a prototype optoelectronic nanohand. Second, they will investigate its optical waveguiding properties. Third, they will investigate optical force exerted by laser beam delivered by the nanohand. Finally, they will investigate in situ electrical and optical characterization, and explore the application of the nanohand.

The intellectual merit is the demonstration and development of new capability to manipulate, control, and characterize individual nanoscale objects. The proposed nanohand has several unique features. It has a large aspect ratio and is free of substrate support. The nanohand has multiple independently controlled nano-actuators or fingers. An object can also be potentially controlled by auxiliary optical force. Finally, electric measurements and optical characterization can be performed to probe a single clenched nanoscale object in situ.

The broader impacts are as follows. The proposed nanohand represents a new class of multi-functional nano-manipulators and can have significant impact on several areas including NEMS/MEMS, optics, and bioengineering. It can open new possibilities for realizing nano-opto-electro-mechanical and nano-robotic systems, for assembling complex three-dimensional nanostructures, and for probing the properties of nanoscale systems and devices at a single nanoparticle or single nanowire level. The multi-disciplinary nature of the proposed research also makes this program an excellent opportunity to educate and train students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have investigated a novel type of optoelectronic nanohand. A general technique for fabrication of the device has been developed by using a micro-structured photonic crystal fiber and carbon nanotubes. The photonic crystal fiber is patterned and selectively infiltrated by pressure pumping molten alloy to form electrodes. We have developed a technique that can ensure continuous filling over the whole length of the fiber (typically tens of inches), which is critical for electrical conduction and electromechanical actuation. We have also developed methods to attach carbon nanotubes to the electrodes by using laser welding and focused ion beam assisted deposition. Prototype nanohand devices have been fabricated. We have also experimentally characterized the electrical and optical properties of the device, including the resisitance of the electrodes, proof-of-concept electromechanical actuation, the optical transmission loss, the modal profile, and the dispersion property. The group velocity dispersion is measured via spectral holography using a supercontinuum source and Mach-Zehnder interferometer. Further, we have performed numerical studies to investigate both the electrical and optical properties of the nanohand, including the deflection of carbon nanotubes under the application of a voltage, optical modal profile, and group velocity dispersion. In addition to the numerical simulation, we have also developed an analytical method that can quantitatively estimate the dispersion and transmission loss of a metal-filled photonic crystal fiber based on the effective index approximation.

The program can have significant impact on several areas including Micro/nano electromechanical systems (MEMS), sensing, and fiber optics. Our research has explored a new route for realizing MEMS devices, which has a high aspect ratio and can thus be potentially advantageous in an environment involving complex geometry. The ability to perform both electrical and optical measurements is a unique feature of the nanohand device, especially useful for sensing applications. The demonstration of an optoelectronic fiber also opens new opportunities for fiber optics, such as modulators or field mediated nonlinear optics. The program has also provided opportunities for research, teaching and mentoring in science and engineering areas. Graduate students have actively participated in the research and been trained by the research activities.
